addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

25 Fe
b
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Musterrolles to be sent by
e next.
Defeat given by
S
r
Fr: Veere.

page.lettertext:
fol.127r
May it please yo
r
good L. there hath no
occasion fallen, to write unto yo
r
L. sins
I sent yo
w
my last,
e 10 of this moneth.
Onely this is as muche, as I can thinke to be
worthy of yo
r
L. knowledge, That wheras
heeretofore
e Province of
Guelders,
upon pre-
tense of unabilitie, hath contributed nothing
in a maner to
e general meanes, for
e main-
tenance of these warres, we are in good hope,
that for
e good successe of
e last sommers ser-
vice in freeing
e Veluwe, and taking in of
Nieumeghen,
w
t
other places adjoining, they will
be drawen to condescend to a 1000
li
by the
moneth: w
ch
I also thinke will be augmented
by
e accesse of
e Impost of
e forsaid places.
The most of
e Deputies of
e
general
states
are arrived heere already, but the
extremitie of
e frost and
e hardnes of the
wether doth stay
e comming of
e rest. By
reason wherof there is nothing yet proposed, nor
no answear yet conceaved, to
e motion in-
tended by
e
Empero
rs
Ambassado
r
.
It should
seeme by a letter of
e Governor of
Bruges,
whiche
hath bin lately intercepted, that upon
e Am-
bassado
rs
advertisments, they are in some hope,
to bring this contrey to a Treaty. It may be
peradventure
at there was never no suche mater
written by
e Ambassado
r
: but whatsoever hath
bin written, I see not wherupon he should take
e lest occasion, to putte himself in
at hope. For
I am fully persuaded,
at his answear will be
suche, as he will wishe he had not taken this
voiage in hand. Heere is nothing nowe but
fol.127v
silence astouching those affaires, every man
expecting when
e states will assemble.
As I have bin required by
e
LL.
of
e Councel,
I have procured a general Muster of all her
Ma
ties
forces, by
e states Commissaries: whiche
was passed long a goe, but their officers are
so slowe in making their certificats,
at as yet
we doe want
e rolles of
Ostend:
albeit we are
advertised,
at
e garrison there was mustered
e last moneth. Those excepted, all
e rest are
consigned to
e handes of
M
r
Wilkes
: and assoone
as those are come, they shall be copied in like ma-
ner, and sent presently after. I was willed
by
e LL. of
e Councel, to deale w
t
e states in
her Ma
ties
name, for
e passing of
e forsaid muster,
and for
e like every moneth, or as often as they see
cause. Howbeit I remembred their lordships,
in my answear, of the old disagreement be-
tween her Ma
tie
and
e states, about
e allowance
of
e dead paies, and certaine other pointes to
w
ch
they never yelded. In w
ch
respect I was
persuaded, that if by order from her Ma
tie
the
mustering of
e Englishe bandes were left to their
officers, considering they will never passe
e dead
paies, in their muster rolles, it might prove unto
her Ma
tie
very prejudiciall. Wherupon for
at
I found,
at I could of my self, and for suche
pretens es, as I signified then, intreat this
Counc-
cel
for
e present to a general Muster, I re-
frained to use
e name of her Ma
tie
. W
ch
their
LL. I hope, will interpret to
e best, and signi-
fie their pleasure, for proceeding heereafter.
The last letter from yow,
at I have re-
ceaved, was of
e 18 of Ja
n
wherto I doe not
fol.128r
doubt, but my former answears have satisfied
yo
r
L.
and so I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. Fe
b
25 1591
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Immediately after
e writing heerof, we re-
ceaved
e rolles of Ostend, whiche shall be
sent w
t
e rest, w
t
in these two daies.
We have also letters from
e states of Gueldres
that S
r
Francis Vere w
t
e forces of those quarters
hath defeated a 100 footemen of
e Enemie,
and taken 38 horse, w
ch
were of
e Garri-
sons neere adjoining.
